evidence: Chrysoloras was invited by Salutati to teach Greek in Florence (1397). Bruni studied under him.
Guarino studied under Chrysoloras in Florence and later followed him to Constantinople for further Greek studies.
Vergerio was among Chrysoloras's students in Florence during his teaching stint 1397-1400.
Argyropoulos was major Greek teacher in Florence; Poliziano was among his students.
Acciaiuoli studied Greek philosophy under Argyropoulos in Florence.
Reuchlin studied Greek with Argyropoulos during his Italian journeys.
Chalcondyles taught Greek in Florence (1475-1491); Reuchlin studied under him.
Both were Greek émigré scholars teaching at Ferrara; colleagues in humanist education.
Salutati, as Chancellor of Florence, mentored Bruni. Bruni wrote dialogues honoring him.
Salutati befriended and mentored young Poggio, setting him on path of Latin and Greek studies.
Salutati's circle included Niccoli as younger member; Salutati encouraged his classical studies.
Filelfo studied rhetoric and Latin under Barzizza in Padua before traveling to Constantinople.
Pico arrived in Florence 1484 and was welcomed into Ficino's circle. Ficino's Neoplatonic framework influenced Pico's work.
Diacceto was Ficino's most important disciple and succeeded him as head of Florentine Platonism.
Nesi was member of Platonic Academy and influenced by Ficinian Platonism.
Both were members of the Platonic Academy under Medici patronage; Landino's commentary on Dante reflects Ficinian influence.
Battista was son of Guarino da Verona and continued his father's educational work at Ferrara.
Hegius was pupil of Agricola; Agricola's humanist methods influenced Hegius's curriculum reforms.
Erasmus attended the school in Deventer; Hegius became headmaster during Erasmus's stay.
Wimpfeling was teacher of Beatus Rhenanus in Alsatian humanist circles.
Grocyn was part of the English humanist circle that shaped More's education.
Colet was part of the English humanist circle with More. His humanist biblical scholarship influenced More and Erasmus.
Extensive correspondence from late 1490s until More's death (1535). Over 100 letters survive. Erasmus dedicated Praise of Folly to More.
Close friendship documented in correspondence and mutual works.
Met during Erasmus's first visit to England (1499). Colet's Oxford lectures influenced Erasmus's approach to biblical scholarship.
Extensive correspondence between the two leading humanists of Northern Europe.
Correspondence documented. Erasmus defended Reuchlin during the Reuchlin Affair.
Vives was a younger friend and correspondent of Erasmus.
Correspondence between Erasmus and the leading Nuremberg humanist.
Beatus Rhenanus was close associate of Erasmus in Basel, serving as editor of his works. After Erasmus's death, Beatus wrote his biography.
Correspondence between two leading biblical humanists.
Close friends and correspondents who met in person multiple times. Extensive letters survive in Petrarch's Epistolae familiares and Seniles.
Close friendship documented in correspondence and visits.
Salutati corresponded with and deeply admired Petrarch. Salutati carried forward Petrarch's humanist program after his death.
Fellow students under Salutati and Chrysoloras. Lifelong friends and correspondents in humanist circles.
Part of same Florentine humanist circle. Sometimes friction in relationship reflected in dialogues and letters.
Fellow members of Florentine humanist circle. Had periods of both friendship and rivalry.
Famous exchange of letters on philosophy vs. rhetoric (1485). Represented debate about style and substance in humanist thought.
Correspondence between two leading philologists of the era.
Close friends and correspondents. Both were Florentine political thinkers. Letters discuss politics, history, and personal matters.
Close friendship documented in correspondence.
Bembo collaborated with Aldus on editions. Pietro Bembo showed Aldus the Roman coin that inspired the Aldine device.
Cosimo provided Ficino with a villa at Careggi and commissioned him to translate Plato's complete works.
Lorenzo continued his grandfather Cosimo's patronage. Ficino dedicated his complete Plato translations (published 1484) to Lorenzo.
Lorenzo protected Pico after some of his 900 Theses were condemned by Pope Innocent VIII (1487). Lorenzo secured Pico's release from imprisonment.
Poliziano entered Lorenzo's circle by dedicating translations of Homer to him. Lorenzo appointed Poliziano tutor to his children.
Landino was member of the Platonic Academy under Medici patronage.
Chalcondyles was professor of Greek in Florence under Lorenzo's patronage; produced first printed edition of Homer (1488).
Valla served at Alfonso V's court in Naples. It was under Alfonso's protection that Valla wrote his exposé of the Donation of Constantine.
Long service to Aragonese kings as secretary and chief minister.
Member of Pontano's academy; served Aragonese court.
Ran famous humanist school in Ferrara for the Este court.
Ran the Casa Giocosa school for Gonzaga family in Mantua.
Budé persuaded Francis I to found the Collège de France (1530) and the royal library at Fontainebleau.
Marguerite protected Lefèvre from prosecution for his religious views.
Nebrija contributed to the Complutensian Polyglot Bible under Cisneros's patronage at Alcalá.
Celtis founded Collegium poetarum at Vienna with support of Emperor Maximilian I.
Bruni saw himself as continuing Petrarch's humanist program of recovering classical learning.
Erasmus rediscovered and published Valla's Annotations on the New Testament (1505), which influenced Erasmus's own biblical scholarship.
Agricola's De inventione dialectica influenced Erasmus's rhetorical approach. Agricola taught Hegius who taught Erasmus.
Both members of Platonic Academy. Poliziano's poetry shows Neoplatonic themes.
Friends and correspondents who influenced each other's political thought. Guicciardini's Ricordi engages with Machiavelli's ideas.
Palmieri's Della vita civile follows the civic humanist tradition established by Bruni.
Erasmus traveled to Venice and worked in Aldus's workshop to prepare the expanded Adagia (published September 1508).
Froben's Basel press published most of Erasmus's major works, making Basel a center of humanist publishing.
Beatus Rhenanus worked with Froben press as editor, collaborating on editions of Erasmus and patristic texts.
Both worked on the Complutensian Polyglot Bible at Alcalá.
Famous controversy over Plato vs. Aristotle. George attacked Plato; Bessarion defended him in In calumniatorem Platonis.
Bitter personal and scholarly rivalry. Exchanged invective-laden treatises attacking each other.
Friendship with periods of bitter rivalry and exchange of invectives.
Initially allies in humanist cause, they broke bitterly over the Reformation. Hutten attacked Erasmus for not fully supporting Luther.
Close friends in Florentine circle. Died the same year (1494). Both buried in San Marco, Florence.
Friends in Florentine intellectual circles. Landino features Alberti in his dialogues.
Niccoli's library of 800 volumes became foundation of Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana through Medici support.
Famous close friendship. After La Boétie's early death, Montaigne devoted his essay 'Of Friendship' to him.
Part of the English humanist circle along with Erasmus, Grocyn, and Linacre.
Part of the same English humanist circle.
Part of the same English humanist circle.
Linacre knew Aldus during his time in Venice studying Greek and medicine.
Colet traveled to Italy and met Ficino, whose Neoplatonic thought influenced Colet's biblical interpretation.
Reuchlin met Pico during Italian travels. Both shared interest in Hebrew and Kabbalah. Pico's Kabbalistic writings influenced Reuchlin.
Sannazaro was member of Pontano's academy; protégé of Pontano.
Both members of Roman Academy. Both imprisoned during 1468 crisis.
Fisher invited Erasmus to teach Greek at Cambridge.
24 books of letters composed 1345-1366, consciously modeled on Cicero's correspondence. Manuscript tradition documented in critical editions.
Biographical collection begun c. 1337, expanded through 1350s. Critical edition by G. Martellotti (1964).
Composed c. 1349-1353. Autograph manuscript (Hamilton 90, Berlin) survives. Critical edition by V. Branca (1976).
Mythological encyclopedia composed 1350-1374. Boccaccio's final autograph survives.
Six books on Latin usage completed c. 1449. Over 60 printed editions by 1536 attest its influence.
De falso credita et ementita Constantini donatione declamatio written 1440 at court of Alfonso V of Naples.
Collatio Novi Testamenti completed c. 1453. Rediscovered by Erasmus at Parc Abbey (1504) and published 1505.
Greek grammar composed c. 1397-1400 for his Florence students. First printed 1471; became standard text for Greek study.
Complete Latin Plato published 1484, first such translation since antiquity. Commissioned by Cosimo de' Medici (1462).
18 books composed 1469-1474, published 1482. Systematic exposition of Platonic philosophy.
Commentary on Plato's Symposium composed 1469. Foundational text for Renaissance Neoplatonic love theory.
Translated 1463 at Cosimo's request, prioritized over Plato. First printed 1471.
Complete Enneads published 1492, first Latin translation. Work begun c. 1484.
Composed 1486 as introduction to his 900 Theses. Never delivered due to papal condemnation; published posthumously 1496.
Conclusiones nongentae published Rome December 1486. 13 propositions condemned by Pope Innocent VIII (1487).
Short treatise composed 1491 to reconcile Plato and Aristotle. Published posthumously 1496.
Panegyric of Florence composed c. 1403-1404, modeled on Aelius Aristides' Panathenaic oration.
Historiarum Florentini populi libri XII composed 1415-1444. First humanist civic history.
New translation from Greek completed 1416-1417, replacing medieval version. Widely copied and printed.
New translation completed 1438, with important preface on translation method.
Composed 1513, circulated in manuscript, published posthumously 1532. Dedicated to Lorenzo de' Medici.
Discourses on first decade of Livy composed c. 1513-1517. Published posthumously 1531.
Commissioned by Cardinal Giulio de' Medici (1520), presented to him 1525. Published 1532.
20 books covering Italian affairs 1490-1534, composed 1537-1540. First printed 1561.
Personal maxims revised in multiple redactions (B, C). Critical edition by Spongano (1951).
Il Libro del Cortegiano composed c. 1508-1516, revised through 1528. Set at court of Urbino c. 1506.
Dialogue on civic life composed c. 1435-1440 in Ciceronian tradition.
De Dignitate et Excellentia Hominis composed 1452-1453, responding to Innocent III's De Miseria Humanae Conditionis.
Educational treatise composed c. 1402-1403, dedicated to Ubertino da Carrara. First humanist treatise on education.
Treatise on teaching method composed c. 1459, codifying his father Guarino da Verona's educational practices.
Composed 1479, published posthumously 1515. Highly influential on humanist logic and rhetoric.
Published 1531 as part of De Disciplinis. Comprehensive humanist educational program.
Composed for John Colet's St. Paul's School, published 1512. Over 150 editions by 1600.
Greek-Latin New Testament published Basel 1516 by Froben. First printed Greek NT. Revised in 5 editions (1516-1535).
Enchiridion militis Christiani (Handbook of the Christian Soldier) first published 1503. Over 20 editions by 1521.
Moriae Encomium composed 1509 at Thomas More's house in London. Dedicated to More; title puns on his name.
Expanded from 1518 schoolbook into satirical dialogues by 1526. Over 100 editions in Erasmus's lifetime.
First edition 1500 (818 proverbs), greatly expanded Aldine edition 1508 (3,260), final edition 1536 (4,151 adages).
Over 3,000 letters survive. Erasmus began publishing his own correspondence 1521. Modern critical edition by P.S. Allen (1906-1958).
New Testament translated 1523, Old Testament 1528. First complete French Bible from original languages.
Published 1506, first Hebrew grammar and lexicon by a Christian scholar. Modeled on David Kimhi's works.
Published 1517, dialogue on Kabbalah dedicated to Pope Leo X. Major text of Christian Kabbalah.
Latin text published Louvain 1516 by Thierry Martens, with preface by Erasmus. Influential political and social satire.
Pastoral romance composed 1480s-1504, published Naples 1504. Founded European pastoral romance tradition.
Unfinished vernacular poem begun 1475 to celebrate Giuliano de' Medici's joust victory.
First centuria (100 chapters) published 1489. Pioneering work of historical-critical philology.
Published in three books (1580, 1588, posthumous 1595 edition). Founded the modern essay genre.
Discours de la servitude volontaire composed c. 1548-1553 in youth, circulated in manuscript, first published 1574.
First printed edition of Homer (Iliad and Odyssey), Florence 1488, sponsored by Lorenzo de' Medici.
Published 1531, expanded editions 1536 and 1543. Standard Latin dictionary for centuries.
Commentarii linguae Graecae published 1529. Major Greek lexicographical work.
Latin version 1435, Italian vernacular (Della pittura) 1436. First systematic Renaissance treatise on painting.
Architectural treatise composed c. 1443-1452, presented to Pope Nicholas V. First printed 1485.
Short treatise on sculpture, date uncertain (c. 1450). Discusses proportions and methods.
Dialogue on family and household management in four books, composed c. 1433-1441.
Topographical study of ancient Rome composed 1444-1446. Pioneer work of Roman archaeology.
Historical geography of Italy composed 1448-1453. First systematic regional survey since antiquity.
Rerum Germanicarum libri tres published 1531. First critical history of Germany using primary sources.
Autobiography composed 1462-1464 while pope. First papal autobiography. Published Rome 1584.
Cardinal Cisneros founded University of Alcalá (1499) and funded the Polyglot Bible project from 1502 until his death in 1517.
Nebrija worked on the Latin text of the Polyglot until disagreements over method led to his departure c. 1514.
Hernán Núñez (El Pinciano) worked on the Greek text of the Complutensian Polyglot at Alcalá.
Ficino was head of the Platonic Academy under Medici patronage.
Pico was a key member of the Platonic Academy.
Poliziano was member of the Platonic Academy.
Landino was member of the Platonic Academy.
Diacceto was Ficino's most important disciple in the Platonic Academy.
Nesi was member of Platonic Academy.
Pomponio Leto founded the Roman Academy.
Platina was member of Roman Academy.
Pontano led the Accademia Pontaniana.
Sannazaro was member of Pontano's academy.
Aldus founded the informal scholarly circle around the Aldine Press.
Bembo collaborated with the Aldine circle.
Celtis founded the Collegium poetarum at Vienna.
Celtis founded humanist sodalities across German-speaking lands.
Pirckheimer was part of German humanist network.
Reuchlin was part of German humanist network.
Aldus Manutius founded the Aldine Press in Venice (1494).
Johann Froben established the Froben Press in Basel.
Robert Estienne was the most prominent member of the Estienne printer family.
Vittorino ran the Casa Giocosa school for the Gonzaga family.
Guarino ran famous school in Ferrara for the Este court.
Battista Guarino continued his father's school at Ferrara.
Salutati was a key figure in civic humanism.
Bruni was the leading theorist of civic humanism.
Palmieri followed the civic humanist tradition.
Ficino founded Renaissance Neoplatonism through his Plato translations.
Pico was a key figure in Renaissance Neoplatonism.
Erasmus was the dominant figure of Northern Christian humanism.
More was a leading figure of Northern humanism.
Colet was a key figure in English Christian humanism.
Reuchlin was a key figure in German humanism.
Budé was the leading French humanist.
Vives was a key figure in Northern humanism.
Lefèvre was the leading French biblical humanist.
Valla was the most important figure in philological humanism.
Poliziano developed historical-critical methods.
Pomponazzi was the most important Renaissance Aristotelian.
Leonico Tomeo was first to lecture on Greek Aristotle at Padua.
Pico was a founder of Christian Kabbalah through his 900 Theses.
Reuchlin was a major figure in Christian Kabbalah through De arte cabalistica.
Ficino was supported by Medici patronage.
Pico was supported by Lorenzo de' Medici.
Poliziano was supported by Medici patronage.
Valla served the papal court.
Biondo served as papal secretary.
Platina was first librarian of Vatican Library.
Erasmus was educated in the tradition of the Devotio Moderna at Deventer.
Hegius connected Devotio Moderna to humanist education at Deventer.
